- theprisoner was in my employment, and had the conducting of that counting-house; he was engaged in the out-door business, and had to collect the money, which he was to enter in the cash-book; this is one of the cash-books, the entries are in his hand-writing; this is the other cashbook, also in his hand-writing - one of these was sent down every Wednesday to me at Birmingham, and on the following morning the other was brought into use in town, so that each of them has the account of an alternate week, and they make together the general cash account - on the 27th of August, 1832, which was Monday, I was in London, and I required the prisoner to give me what bills and cash he had; he gave me two bills, and cash amounting to 125l., but we did not balance on that day - on the Wednesday following, I was still in town, and I required him to balance his account as usual; he begged it might stand till the next morning; and on that day, which was the 30th, he made up the account in his own hand-writing - here it is from the 22nd to the 29th of August; it ought to have included the receipts of all monies within that time; it is entered here, "Received of
George Boulton
, on the 28th a two month's bill 13l., a thirty-day bill 9l. 10s., and cash 29l. 7s. 8d., making a total of 51l. 17s. 8d.;" there is no other account of any further receipt from Mr. Boulton, as of that period - in November last I had a customer of the name of Fairburn; in this cash account, which begins on November the 14th, and ends on the 22nd, and is made up and balanced in the prisoner's writing, (and was sent to me at Birmingham,) I find this entry,"November 20th, from
Robert Fairburn
two month's bill 18l., cheque 8l. 10s., total 26l. 10s." - I find, on the 26th of November, "from Robert Fairburn 16l. 8s. 9d.," but that is another account, it has no reference to this; here is no account of the receipt of 9l. 10s. from Fairburn; this 16l. 8s. 9d. is the balance of the account to July - I discharged the prisoner on the 29th of May last - a book was kept in my counting-house, containing the entries in both the cash-books; this is the book, it is in the prisoner's writing - the balance he makes due to me at the time I discharged him is 60l. 5s. 1d. - I called his attention to it, as it was unusually large, he appeared confused; I looked stedfastly at him, and said "I wish you to produce the money, lay it on the desk;" he said if I wished him to produce the money, I should have given him three or four days' notice; "Not I," said I, "I wish you to produce what you have" - he put his hand into his pocket, and produced 5s. 1d. - I asked what he had done with the remainder, he said he had made use of it; I replied,"That being the case, I cannot think of employing you any longer, I therefore now discharge you, and request you to give up your keys," which he did - he said if I would forgive him, his friends should pay the money; I told him that was out of the question - he then left the warehouse - I made no criminal charge against him for that balance - about the middle of July I discovered he had received monies which were not entered in the book, and I had him apprehended - he had 150l. a-year salary.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you been in the Birmingham business? A. More than twenty years - the firm was originally Jenkins and Hands, Jenkins was my father, and Hands was his cousin - I was an apprentice there, and so was the prisoner; I don't recollect whether it was it the same time - the prisoner was not engaged for a rival house when I had him taken into custody, to my knowledge.

Q. Upon your oath, did you not know that he was engaged in executing the commission of a rival house, and were you not expressly informed of it by his brother? A. On my oath, I did not know it - I do not know that he was engaged for any house in the same business; I did not know he was engaged to sell on commission, or in any other way for any house in Birmingham or any where else; I know Mr.
Paul Moore
of Birmingham; I did not know that the prisoner was engaged in business for him - I never heard that he was, or was about to be; I heard in the early part of July, that he had been in negotiation with Mr. Moore - Mr. Moore is a manufacturer in the same line of business as I am; I never employed the prisoner by commission - I offered him a commission to take place subsequent to Midsummer last; that was the subject of conversation in the early part of this year; I did not offer him that after the 29th of May - I am quite sure of that - I cannot say positively how much my returns have increased since the prisoner came into my service; he met me at Stony-Stratford in September, 1831, to look over the business of the establishment, but nothing was then mentioned about increase of salary - he mentioned that I had not given him credit for the present I had been in the habit of giving him - I wished him to leave the house of mine which he occupied, and I told him I would give him 30 a-year in lien of it; I cannot tell whether 52 a-year was mentioned, it might be matter of conversation - I never said that I would give it him; his salary was 120 a-year, and 30 additional for leaving the premises in Queen-street, where he had resided free of rent, coals and candles.

Q. Did you ever say that you had been studying how to improve his situation, and that the conclusion you had come to was, that instead of his receiving 120 a-year as formerly, that from the 1st of January, 1832, he should be entitled to a commission of one per cent on all monies received? A. There was a proposal for a commission on his part, to which I did not consent - I did say I had been studying how to improve his situation; I had been in the habit of giving him a present, and I might have given him more - I had a very good opinion of him; I did not succeed to the business of his friends at Birmingham, they live in another part of the town - I swear positively and without reserve, that I never agreed to allow the prisoner any commission of any kind on any occasion; on the 30th of March, 1832, I sent him a statement of accounts desiring him to examine and return them, but he never returned them - I don't recollect his writing to me to say that the statement was not in accordance with my agreement, to allow him a commission of one per cent; I have no knowledge of his objecting to that statement.

Q. When you discharged him on the 29th of May, did he not remonstrate with you on your conduct, and say that you were to allow him a commission, and that you had sent him a statement which he had returned, as not being in accordance with your own agreement? A. No; he appeared a good deal affected, and said his friends should make good the deficiency; he said nothingabout commission - I have no recollection on the 9th of June, of receiving any application from him, to be furnished with an account of the money received since he had commenced on commission - I will not swear it was not made, I don't recollect it - I think that a commission of one per-cent on the sale of goods would have fallen short of his salary; the prisoner called upon me about the end of June, to know if I would reinstate him in his situation; he did not mention the accounts; I have no recollection of his saying a word about them; I will swear he did not; it is probable I might tell him I should be in town in three weeks, and he might call upon me again.

Q. Did he at that interview inform you that he was about to join a gentleman in partnership, and mention several commissions that had been offered to him? A. I don't recollect it - I don't recollect that he mentioned a commission from Mr.
Paul Moore
; he mentioned a per-centage from Mr. Moore, but whether at that, or an after interview I cannot tell - I have no recollection of its being at that meeting, but some such a point was a matter of conversation - I don't recollect his saying he should be at Birmingham in ten days, and he would wait upon me there; he came to Birmingham, but I cannot tell at what time, he called upon me at my warehouse; and I said I wished to see his brother before I had any conversation with him.

Q. Will you swear you did not say that you wished to see his brother before you entered into any arrangement with him? A. I have no recollection of it; I cannot speak to the precise words - I wished to see his brother - I said I would call upon his brother; I cannot swear I did not use the word "arrangement;" I called on his brother the same evening, he was going to tea, but I did not drink tea with him; I received a visit from the prisoner and his brother, but I don't know whether it was on the following day; I had some conversation about his receiving a commission on the sale of brass and copper metal, but I did not enter into any arrangement - his brother had an agent in London of the name of Stevens, with whom it was stated the prisoner was about to go into partnership in the commission business, and his brother asked me if I had any objection to give him some commission, if he should succeed in going into partnership - and I said if anything fell in his way to sell to customers whose names were not on my books, I should have no objection to allow him a commission; I can swear this was in June or the beginning of July - it was before I discovered this; he stated that he had been offered a better commission from Mr. Moore than from me; I don't recollect his saying he would not take mine.

Q. Did not his brother ask you this plain question;"Mr. Jenkins, am I to understand that if my brother accepts the commission from Mr. Moore, that he will have nothing to fear from you as it respects his account with you?" A. I have no recollection of his making use of such an observation - I might say - "Certainly not; I will be no obstacle to him, I wish him well;" I had no hostile feeling towards him, until I discovered the money had been received and not entered in the book - none of these charges had then been brought to my knowledge.

Q. Now so far from your not knowing that he had been acting for Mr. Moore - did he not on his return to Birmingham, a week afterwards, call and tell you that he had arranged with Mr. Moore and taken his business? A. He never did, nor did his brother either; I came to London on a Saturday night, in the early part of August, and the prisoner came to me on the Monday after - I do not know what he came for; he said, he wanted to speak to me; I told him I was so engaged I could not speak to him then, but I should be at liberty at nine o'clock in the evening - I had made some discovery before he came, and he was soon after taken into custody, but they were matters distinct from this indictment; I had no knowledge of these at the time - I have had no communication with the prisoner since he has been in custody; the book has not been shown to him since.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Just tell me the amount of the present you were in the habit of making him? A. 10l. a year; I remitted to him money on account of his salary once a month; April was the last time; I have had his acknowledgment for them; there had been conversation about allowing him a commission from June in the present year, if he had continued with me, but it was never acted upon - at the time I saw him at Birmingham I had no reason to believe that there was any account between us, but that which left him in debt that 60l.; and when I went before the Lord Mayor I was not aware of the items in this indictment.

GEORGE BOULTON. I am a needle and pin-maker. I deal with the prosecutor; I knew the prisoner in his employ - I settled this account with him on the 23rd of August, 1832, by bill 13l., bill 9l. 10s., cash 34l. 10s. making a total of 57l. - the bill was 57l. 12s. 4d., here is the prisoner's receipt for it - (read.) "Allowed 12s. 4d. for W. Jenkins and Son - G. R. Hands."

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long had you dealt with the prosecutor? A. I am not certain, perhaps two years or more - this bill is headed, Jenkins and Son; I am not certain whether all the bills are so; I had returned to the prosecutor, on the 9th of February, 2 cwt. of old metal, which came to 4l. 10s. - I cannot say whether the 4l. 10s. was due to me for that metal when I paid this bill - the prisoner used to go to my clerks, and they settled it.

Q. Can you undertake to say whether on this occasion, you paid the prisoner bills and money amounting to 57l., or that you paid this bill deducting 4l. 10s. and the 12s. 4d.? A. No, I paid him 57l. in money and bills.

ROBERT FAIRBURN. I am a wire-drawer, and live in Old-street. I dealt with the firm of Jenkins and Son, in 1832; I knew the prisoner as their clerk; this is my account with their firm, it is 45l. 4s., but it was originally 35l. 4s. - on the 20th of November, 1832, here is the prisoner's receipt for a bill 18l.; cheque 8l. 10s.; and cash 8l. 14s. making together 35l. 4s. and signed, G. R. Hands - the account was only 35l. 4s. but it was 10l. short, and he called the next morning, and said, he had made a mistake, and reckoned it too little - I then paid him 9l. 10s. more, and here is the 10s. he allowed for discount.
MR. JENKINS re-examined. Have you any partner? A. No; I trade under the firm of Jenkins and Son; I did allow my father a settled sum out of the business, but it did not depend on the trade.

JURY. Q. What is the usual credit of your trade? A. We profess to give six months, but it often extends to eight or nine months; but a great many of our customers pay earlier; some only one month; no doubt money has been received, both from Mr. Boulton and Mr. Fairburn since these embezzlements, but I did not examine my ledger with reference to these sums till after the prisoner was committed by the Lord Mayor - I had a regular debtor and creditor account with those persons, but the collecting was in the prisoner's hands till he was discharged, so that I had no means of discovering it - our accounts are sent in half-yearly, or in some cases quarterly; if any objection had been made to these accounts, it would not have come to me but through the prisoner.

COURT. Q. Who kept the ledger? A. Mr. Alccck; these sums appear in the ledger, but the prisoner had the settlement of all accounts - I received information that there was a deficiency in these accounts, and then I looked over the ledger and found it; I then applied to the parties, to know what had been paid.

The prisoner, in his defence, read a very long address, stating that he had been for some years in the prosecutor's service, and that he had exerted himself to increase his business, which he had from 100l. to 400l. per week; that the prosecutor had offered to allow him one per cent. commission on all monies received from Christmas, 1832, but which he had never done; that having been discharged without any notice he had no time to correct any errors, which might have crept into the account, and that he had not been since allowed to settle, and that he firmly believed there was now a balance in his own favour.

Mr. Wood, Newcastle-street; Mr. Simmons, Birmingham; Mr. Lewis, Bow-street; Mr. Stevens, Thaives-inn; Mr. Jones, Grafton-street; Mr. Linford, Doctors-commons; Mr. Jackson, Butcher-hall-lane; and Mr. Joyce, of Wood-street, gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY. Aged 43. -
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined Eighteen Months .
OLD COURT. Wednesday, September 11, 1833.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, Before Mr. Baron Gurney.

1340.
WILLIAM RICHMOND
was indicted for,
that he, on the 6th of July , having in his possession a certain bill of exchange , which is as follows:
"111 1s. 6d. London, 1st July, 1829.

Three months after date, pay to my order, 111 1s. 6d. value received.
ROBERT WILSON
.
To Mr. D. Clark, Merchant, 12, Commercial Chambers. Minories."
feloniously did forge upon the same an acceptance thereof, which is as follows:

"No. 129, due the 14th of October; accepted for 111 1s. 6d. payable at No. 12, Commercial Chambers, Minories, D. Clark." with intent to defraud
Barrett Wadden
, against the statute, &c.
2 OTHER COUNTS charging the prisoner with uttering.

BARRETT WADDEN. I am a silk manufacturer . In 1829, I had a warehouse in White-lion-street, Spitalfields - the prisoner applied to me to purchase some silk, and purchased one thousand and eighty-one yards, value 209l. 10s. he proposed paying me according to the terms of a note he had written to me a few days previous - that if I would sell him the goods he would give me half the amount in money, and an approved bill for the other half, which bill was to be delivered to me on the Saturday following - the sale was made on Monday, the 29th of June, 1829, the goods were delivered, and he gave a cheque for 104l. on a house, in Lombard-street, which cheque was paid - in consequence of information, I afterwards received, I saw him on the following Wednesday -(that was two days after) I saw him at his warehouse, in Gutter-lane - I went there and said to him, "Richmond, the goods I sold you last Monday, you have offered for sale at Swan & Co.'s Regent-street, at a price much less than you bought them of me for; I evidently see a fraud is intended - I give you your choice of two things, send me back my goods and I will return the 104l., or if that is not done, I shall apply to the Lord Mayor, and charge you with defrauding me out of the goods; the goods have been offered to Swan & Co. for 20l. less than the invoice" - he denied it, but said, the goods he had offered the night before to Swan & Co. were not the goods he had bought of me, but goods he had got at another house, and which he could afford to sell at that price - I left the warehouse, for two strangers to me were present - and when I returned home, I wrote him a note, and received an answer to that note, which answer, I have here - I know his hand-writing - it is in his handwriting. (read.)

"Mr. Wadden, Sir - I duly received your note of this day, and in reply to which, I beg to inform you, that you are at perfect liberty to act as you may think proper; but must add, that should you persist in acting under your present mistake, I shall most reluctantly be compelled to proceed as my solicitor now dictates. I have bitherto fulfilled my engagements, by paying you half the amount in cash - I shall give you the remainder in indorsed papers, on Saturday, which is the day I promised.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant, W. RICHMOND." I waited until the following Saturday - I had no communication from him on Saturday - on the following Monday, when I came to my business, a letter was handed to me, by my clerk - it is the hand-writing of the prisoner - the direction is in his hand-writing - when I opened it, this bill was inside it, but nothing whatever besides it is only an envelope - the direction is, to "Mr. B. Wadden White-lion-street, Spitalfields;" this is the bill that was inside it - the moment I received this bill, before I acknowledged the receipt of it, or placed it to the credit of his account - I immediately proceeded to No. 12, Commercial Chambers, Minories; I inquired there for D. Clark; I could find no person of that name; I then handed the bill to my solicitor, requesting he would proceed immediately - I went to Gutter-lane, to the prisoner's warehouse, he was not there, nor was there any person there who knew anything about him - I found no clerk there - the front-door of his warehouse was locked I got into a place at the back of the warehouse - I found the warehouse locked up - I never saw the prisoner fromthe 1st of July, 1829, until the 6th of August last - when I met him, in Cockspur-street, he doffed his hat to me, as I passed - I turned round; (I walking in one direction and he in another,) I walked up to him, and said, "Richmond, is it possible that I see you in London," he said,"It is, sir;" I said, "Are you aware of the situation you have placed yourself in; you have absconded from your creditors, you are a bankrupt, and an outlaw, are you aware of this?" he replied, "I am aware of it;" I then said,"Are you aware you have passed me a bill, which I have good reason to believe is a forgery," he said, "I am a very unfortunate man, Mr. Wadden," I said "What do you intend to do with yourself?" he said, "I know not; all that I can do I have done, I have sent my books to the agent to the Commission" - I then took him by the collar of the coat, and said, "Here I shall keep you till I place you in the hands of the Police;" he said, "For God's sake do no such thing, Mr. Wadden - I entreat you not to do it;" I said, "Ah, but I will do it;" and finding I would not let him go, a struggle took place, we struggled into the middle of the street; he broke from me, and ran as hard as he could - I pursued him, crying,"Stop," some persons joined in the pursuit, and he was secured in Spring-gardens - I kept him there till I gave him up to the police, at Queen-square office.

EDWARD CHURCH
. I am an attorney. Mr. Wadden put this bill into my hands - I never saw the prisoner about it until he was taken - I went to Gutter-lane, to his warehouse, and found a boy who gave his name as Kirk, he said, he was Richmond's clerk - I did not find Richmond - I stated what I had come about; I found the warehouse quite empty, quite stripped of every parcel of goods, and furniture, of every description - I went to where the bill was made payable, and inquired for Mr. Clark, but could not find any such person there.

WILLIAM ADAMSON
. I am an inspector of Police - the prisoner did belong to the Police; he joined it in September, last year, and resigned in November - I know his hand-writing, (looking at the indorsement of the bill,) this is his hand-writing.

JOHN JOSEPH MANNOCK
. I am clerk to Mr. Wadden - I received the letter, which he found, on coming to his warehouse - I received it from a lad, about ten o'clock in the morning, before Mr. Wadden came to town, and gave it to him when he arrived at the warehouse; it was wafered - I delivered it to him in the same state in which I received it.

The prisoner in an address to the Court, stated, that his affairs became involved in the year 1829, when he was introduced to a man named Clark, who held out flattering prospects to him, and persuaded him to go to France - that Clark and himself had accepted bills for each other; Clark was to remit the cash to a friend of his at the Commercial Chambers, where they were made payable.

DANIEL LAY
, JUN. I am a clerk in the office of Oliverson & Co., solicitors, Old Jewry, and was so in 1828 - I knew a person named George Delianson Clark, I do not know where he lived; I did not know him when I arrested him; I did not of my own knowledge know where he lived - I arrested him at the suit of Pulley, Pear, and Field - I did not go with the officer to arrest him - I saw him; he was arrested about the 9th of February, 1828, and remained in custody till after the 29th of May, but I cannot say how long - I never saw him at that time but once; I saw him two or three times, in 1831 - I have seen him write, I think this is his hand-writing, it is signed merely D. Clark - I have seen him write two or three times.

COURT. Q. What did you see him write? A. An assignment which I prepared - I saw him sign it - he signed it, "George Delianson Clark," at the same time I saw him write some letters or memorandums; I read them - that was in 1831, when he was in custody.

JOHN LARGE
. I am a coachmaker. I knew Mr. Delianson Clark, in 1829 - I did not know him by the name of George - I have had transactions with him, in the way of business, and took an acceptance from him - I have seen him write several times - I doubt the acceptance to this bill being his hand-writing; it is not signed the same as mine; the signature is not certainly like the one I have - I have letters from him - this signature is not like his certainly, as far as I am able to judge.

THOMAS PARK
. I am a wine-merchant, and live in America-square, Minories - in 1829 I had apartments in Commercial Chambers - I knew
George Delianson Clark
, in 1828 - I had no transactions with him in the way of business - I saw him at my chambers; he called to induce me to accept for him while he was in Paris; he told me he was going to Paris, and I received letters from him at Paris - I have seen him write perhaps ten or twelve times - I should say the acceptance, of this bill, is not his hand-writing; he always signed his name in full, Delianson Clark; and his letters from Paris were always signed the same way - the hand-writing is in every respect is like his - I believe it to be his - I never had any dealings with him.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you ever a bill of his acceptance? A. Never; he drew on me - I believe the whole of this to be his writing, signature and all; it is very much like his writing - I should say it was his writing, and act on it.

WILLIAM LAYWOOD
. I am a solicitor at Furnival's-inn. I have been concerned for George Delianson Clark, he goes by the name Delianson, and George Delianson Clark - I have every reason to believe he is now at Brussels - I have seen him write several times within the last three months - I believe this bill of exchange to be the hand writing of Mr. Clark.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you seen him in 1829 write at all? A. I have not known him till about three months ago - I became acquainted with him the latter end of April - I believe he left London the 6th or 7th of last month, for Brussels - I have seen him write at least ten times - I never saw him accept a bill.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you acted on the letters you received from him? A. I have.

WILLIAM POPE
. I am an oilman, and live in Commercial-road, East - I know George Delianson Clark - I have seen him write three or four times, and perhaps more - the acceptance of this bill I have no doubt is in his hand writing.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you keep a shop in the Commercial-road? A. Yes, for a few months - I did not keepanything before that - I was in the Excise-office, some time last year - I was never constantly there.
COURT. Q. What were you in the Excise? A. Sometimes they want general clerks there.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You were a writer there? A. Yes - I got my living by industry before - about four years ago I married; my wife had some property, and through her and her friends I supported myself; I have not had bills from Clark - we have corresponded very little indeed - I met him at a friend's - I saw him write something appointing me to meet him - I have seen him write three or four times - it must be full four years ago - I have seen nothing of him since to my knowledge.

MARIA WILSON
. My husband's name was Robert, he is the drawer of this bill; and that in his signature - my husband died on the 25th of January, 1831.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. This is your husband's signature? A. Yes - I know nothing about the bill - I never saw or heard of it before - the indorsement is my husband's also- I knew Mr. Richmond when my husband was living - when he lived in Gutter-lane - between four and five years ago - I did not know him myself long before he left - my husband knew him - my husband was brought up as a lawyer and practised as such in the country, but had not taken his certificate out in the city - he lived in Trinity-street, Borough - he practised in the north.

COURT. Q. What did he do when he lived in Southwark? A. He was not doing anything - I cannot exactly tell how long it was since he practised - he was not doing anything in 1829 - he was not living in the rules of the King's Bench - he was living in Trinity-street, Trinity-square, over London-bridge, nearly opposite Union-hall, leading out of High-street - he got his living with the assistance of my friends.

JAMES PALMER
. I am a sadler, living at Star-corner, Bermondsey. I knew Robert Wilson - I have seen him write - I believe this signature to be his hand writing - I believe this indorsement to be his hand writing - I have frequently seen him write - he used to write for me frequently.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long ago? A. I suppose about four years ago - he was a solicitor - he used frequently to make out my accounts - he had nothing to do at that time - I have not seen him write his name, or accept a bill - he wrote in my books - I have not looked at those books for three or four years.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you receive any letters from him? A. No - he mostly made out my bills - he wrote not only figures but words - I paid him for it - he assisted as a kind of clerk.

MR. PARK. I knew Delianson Clark, he frequently called on me - he did not to my knowledge live at No. 12, Commercial-chambers - I have chambers there - Clark came backwards and forwards doing business - he never held chambers there - he never came there except to me - to my knowledge; I never authorised him to make bills payable there.

WILLIAM POPE
. I know Clark and the prisoner were acquainted.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Gurney.

1402.
JOHN TURNER
was indicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
Elizabeth Greswood
.

THOMAS GRESWOOD
. I am the father of
Elizabeth Greswood
, and live at No. 7, White Lion-street, Seven-dials - I saw her last, about a week before this happened - she died in Middlesex Hospital - she was six years old last June.

JAMES WHITE
. I sell fruit in the street. On the 12th of August, I was in High-street, Bloomsbury
, selling my fruit within a short distance of the church - about forty yards from where the accident happened - I saw two omnibuses both coming down towards Holborn, driving at full gallop - they appeared to be racing - I saw the deceased going across the road - she got clear of the omnibus next her - she was going from the near side to the off side - she passed the first omnibus, and was run down by the other, and both wheels ran over her; both omnibuses were pretty near abreast at the time, there was very little difference between them - I don't know the driver - it was Bardell's omnibus - the other was Shillibeer's.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there anybody with the child ? A. Another child was playing with her, before she started to cross - it was not a regular crossing place - the child ran across - the first omnibus was very near her when she attempted to cross - I think the man pulled up as soon as he possibly could - the child was a good deal more than a yard or two from the omnibus when she attempted to cross, but they came at such a rate the child could not cross - she was able to run very well - it is a narrow part of the street - the street was not dirty; I think Shillibeer's omnibus went a good distance before it pulled up - the man by whom the accident happened pulled up as soon as he possibly could.
COURT. Q. Did he pull up before the child was run over? A. No - both wheels went over the child.

JOHN CONROY
. I am inspector of nuisances for the parish of St. Giles's. On the 12th of August, I was near St. Giles's church about a quarter to two o'clock - I saw two omnibuses, but the driver of Bardell's omnibus was in the act of pulling up, when I saw it - Shillibeer's passed on thirty or thirty-five yards, and then stopped - I had not seen either of them before - I saw Bardell's in the act of pulling up - I saw the child taken in to a surgeon's - I took the numbers of the omnibuses - Bardell was No. 194, and drawn by two horses.

OSBORNE BARKER
. I am a farrier, and live in Hampshire-hog-yard. I was in St. Giles's, and saw both the omnibuses before the accident, driving at a moderate pace - I was standing outside of the Angel Inn - the omnibuses were going by - the child appeared to pass Shillibeer's, and the other omnibus came in contact with her - the near horse knocked her down, and the two wheels passed over her body - I could not see any blame that could be attached to the driver, it was so sudden - I instantly took the child up - I was examined before the Coroner - there was room sufficient for Bardell's omnibus to go by - when I saw Bardell's it was about passing the other - it was in the broad part of the street at that time, and there was sufficient room - the Angel joins the church - the omnibusses were beyond me a few yardstowards Holborn - they were nearer Holborn - they had passed me near Compton-street - they had not got to Compton-street - it might be one house from Compton-street - I consider Bardell's omnibus was not going seven miles an hour - it could not be going eight - I said before the Coroner that Bardell's, was going faster than the other - not that it was going very fast, but that it was going faster than Shillibeer's.

Q. Is that your hand writing? A. That is my hand writing - it was read over to me - I said Bardell's was going faster than Shillibeer's - I meant to say it was passing it - I did not see it pass Shillibeer's - but the child had run across, and must have passed Shillibeer's - when I first saw her, she was under the near side horse's head, about being knocked down.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you also said before the Coroner, that these two omnibuses were not racing? A. I did; according to what I considered myself - I certainly did not take particular notice in respect to saying Bardell's was going very fast - for I consider, when an omnibus is going between seven and eight miles an hour it is not such a rapid pace - in my judgment they were not racing - I saw the man who drove Bardell's omnibus, try his utmost to pull up before the child was knocked down - if it had been his own child, he could not have avoided the accident.

WILLIAM EDMUND RAMSEY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in High-street, Bloomsbury. I was at my window and saw the two omnibuses coming very fast, they appeared to be racing - I saw the child; it passed by the head of Shillibeer's omnibus - it was knocked down by the other one - the other was coming on the off side of Shillibeer's - I did not see it knocked down - I saw the omnibus stop - I saw the child under the hind wheel - it did not stop before that - they were coming I should suppose, at the rate of ten miles an hour - the horses were galloping - the prisoner was the driver of Bardell's omnibus.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You were looking through your shop-window? A. Yes; watches and various things hung in the window.
COURT. Q. Had you a good sight of them? A. I had; not only from the window, but from the door - we had nothing hanging at the door.

WILLIAM RANDALL
(a policeman). I was on duty near the church - I saw the two omnibuses going at a very rapid rate, both of them galloping - I did not see the child before it was down; I saw it under the wheel - the omnibus then stopped, the driver drew up as soon as possible, from the cries of the people - the omnibus was on the off side of the road; the two appeared to me to be racing; it appeared he was trying to turn round on the off side to pass the other, his horses' heads had come to the hind part of Shillibeer's omnibus - I saw the child taken to the surgeon's, it was then taken to the Middlesex-hospital.

ANN HARRIET DABWELL
. I was near St. Giles's church, and saw the two omnibuses - I was waiting for them to pass me to cross the road; they were both of them driving at a furious rate; the horses were galloping- I was close to the back of the omnibus, going to cross, when I saw the child under the wheel - that was the omnibus on the off side; they appeared to me to be racing; I think Bardell's was endeavouring to get a-head of the other.

MARY READY
. I saw the two omnibuses, I was standing two doors from the pawnbroker's - they were going at full gallop, and appeared to be racing; one trying to get before the other; Bardell's was trying to get before the other - I did not see the child till it was under the hind wheel.

CHARLES PURCHASE
. I live at No. 14, High-street - I was looking out of window, and saw the omnibuses coming down by the White Lion, from that part nearly to the Angel - they were coming at a tremendously fast rate, between nine and ten miles an hour; Bardell's was galloping - I turned my head, and made a remark to my son, at what I observed, and when I put my head to the window again and looked out I saw the child in the man's arms, after seeing them galloping I had looked off.

ROBERT ELLIOTT
. I am assistant to Mr. Bartholomew, a surgeon - the child was brought in to me; I found it injured, and directed it to be taken to the hospital.

ELIZABETH BALIN
. I heard the screams of the people. and ran out and stopped the horses; the driver never came off his box, but said if I did not go away he would run over half a dozen of us - I understood it was my child that was run over; I begged the people to take the number of the omnibus - I took the child to the doctor's, and then to the hospital, and stopped with it till I saw the last of it - it died that night.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you before the Coroner? A. No, I was not; the man never pulled up - others heard the expressions I have named - I stopped the horses, and the people dragged me away from the horses' heads, but who they were I cannot tell - I was in a great fright, for I had reared the child ever since it was ten months' old; I am her grandmother - I live close by; the child had not been two minutes out of my place.

JOHN GILL
. I am a house surgeon at the Middlesex hospital - the child was brought there; I found her very much bruised on the left side of the belly; she died about half-past eight o'clock that evening, from a rupture of the spleen, and a quantity of blood extravasated in the abdomen, which would no doubt be caused by being run over.

MR. PHILLIPS to ELIZABETH BALIN. Q. Were you at the hospital? A. Yes; I saw the prisoner's wife there, at the foot of the bed - I saw the prisoner outside, leaning on a post; I had something to drink with the prisoner's wife - there was no offer made on the part of the prisoner, to pay all the expenses of the funeral.

Prisoner's Defence. There are are several people in the court it appears to me have been false swearing themselves - the grandmother never came near my horses' heads; in fact, the conductor took the child from under the wheel, and ran across the road with it - a man held my horses' heads, and the farrier stood by the fore wheel; there was no woman there at all - they said I ought to be taken off the box, I said "What for?" a gentleman in the omnibus said "What do you want to take him off the box for?" - I staid until the policeman took my name and number; then he gave me orders to go - I never saw the child till it was under the horses; Ipulled up the moment I knew of it, and it was under the wheel.

HUMPHREY JONES
, I am living on my property, at No. 3, Little Marlborough-street - I was in the prisoner's omnibus when this unfortunate occurrence took place; I was as near the horses as could be, looking through the front window; I could see the horses - the one next to me was not galloping; I could not see the off side one- I saw this poor child, I was sitting with my face towards the church; we were a little beyond the church, and looking through the window - there had been a little stoppage just before, and it was impossible to gallop without galloping over a carriage - I saw a child run from my back, she ran almost as quick as a bird could fly, she appeared to wish to get over the road before the carriage passed; I saw her come all of a sudden, and run so fast, I could not tell whether it was male or female - I was afraid there would be an accident; the driver was by no means to blame, he must be something more than man if he could have prevented it - I never saw him before.

SABINA WALTERS
. I was in the service of Mr. Brown, of Ludgate-hill - I was in the omnibus that run over the child; the horses were not galloping they had stopped a short time before, I think it was to take up a passenger; we had got about eight or nine yards from the place when the accident happened - I saw the child leave the footpath, there was no crossing at that place; the child ran into the danger- the driver pulled up as soon as he possibly could; I don't think he could have avoided the accident; he was sober.

COURT. Q. Were you inside the omnibus? A. Yes; if I could see the child leave the path, the coachman could - the other omnibus was between us and the footpath; it was not close to us, we were passing the other omnibus; we had come up to it - I saw the child through the windows; the other omnibus was not between us and the path - I was sitting on the right-hand side, in the middle of the omnibus, on the opposite side to where the child was; and the other omnibus was at my left, and the pathway to my left - there were no better means for me to see the child more than the coachman; he was more forward than me, and higher; he was turning his head when the child was leaving the pathway.

JAMES WYBRUN
. I was the driver of Shillibeer's omnibus - I saw the child under the wheel of Bardell's omnibus, after I had stopped and turned my head round- I don't know at what rate Bardell's omnibus was going; I was going about six miles an hour - I was a-head of him; I was not racing against his omnibus; I did not know he was so close behind me; I was not racing against anything - I think Bardell's had the best horses, but the prisoner had never attempted to go by me, all the road from Paddington.

FRANCIS SKINNER
. I was conductor of Shillibeer's omnibus; I had come with it from Paddington - Bardell's at that time I think had the best horses - on our way from Paddington to the Bank Bardell's omnibus had not made the least attempt to pass us, except when we stopped to take up a passenger - I had the opportunity of observing the accident; the prisoner pulled up as soon as possible.

WILLIAM HEDGES
. I am a sadler, and live in Edgware-road - I was in Shillibeer's omnibus, on the day in question - I was taken up in the Edgware-road - I rode to St. Giles' church, they came very pleasantly all the way; I should think about five or six miles an hour, at a regular rate - there was no racing - I remember hearing of the accident perfectly well; we were standing still fifty-five yards on this side Moumouth-street, when I saw the child in the road, and I said, "That child will be killed," and it was run over at that very moment; it was not a proper crossing place at all - no blame at all was to be attributed to the prisoner.

- CLARK. I was in St. Giles's, near Shillibeer's Omnibus; I am a baker and live in Junction-terrace, Edgeware-road; I witnessed the accident, there was no blame to be attributed to the driver of Bardell's omnibus, he pulled up immediately.

- HAND. I am a milkman, and live at Hampstead. I was sitting in a window, in St. Giles's, and saw the omnibuses going at the rate of seven or eight miles an hour - I observed the accident; they were not racing - no blame at all was to be attributed to the driver - he pulled up as quick as he could.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. - Wednesday, September 11, 1833.
London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1403.
JOSEPH STONE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 5th of August
, from an evil disposed person, 1 tea-chest, value 1s.; and 80 lbs. of tea, value 17l., the goods of
John Nicholson
, knowing the same to have been stolen .
MR. AYCKBONE conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN NICHOLSON
. I am a tea-agent , and live in Fenchurch-street. I purchased the chest of tea stated in the indictment, at the June tea sale; it stands in my list in the third class, and is described by the Company's tea tasters, as middling Congon - I had it at 2s. 2d. and the duty is the same, which made it 4s. 4d. per lb.; it was left in the warehouse as is usual till it is wanted, and I had never made out any order at any time for its being delivered - about the 12th or 13th August, I heard it was gone I then missed it from my warrant.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you know that there is such a thing as smuggled tea? A. I have heard there is - if tea is exported we do not pay the duty; if a person were to take tea to the opposite side of the channel and smuggle it back, he could have it without the duty - I had paid the duty for this; it was a lot of nine I had paid for; this chest was No. 677 by the Edinboro; that number was marked on the chest; I did not pay the duty on this chest myself, but my clerk did; I have no partner - I know Collins, he keeps a store shop and deals in very thing - I think it is likely that he deals in tea as well as other things, though I have no knowledge of it; I never heard that the prisoner was his servant - I have no recollection of hearing that before the Lord Mayor; I will not swear that it was not distinctly stated as the ground of the prisoner's defence that he was the servant of Collins - I preferred a bill against Collins on the evidence of Thompson, a servant of mine, who had been robbing me; the Lord Mayor sent him to the Compter - as soon as I missed the tea, I inquired of Thompson, andhe made a statement, on which I admitted him as evidence; I preferred a bill against Collins, which was thrown out by the Grand Jury - I had not seen Collins after I was at the Mansion-house; he has not been at my house nor I at his; I have no knowledge of his being a man of property - I never heard any intimation that money was no object; I never heard a sum of 150l. mentioned.

JURY. Q. Do you generally have possession of your tea warrants? A. Yes, every night; on the 5th of August, I delivered this warrant to Thompson; he had to clear with the warrant; the other eight chests had all been permitted, and sent to different persons in the country before that day.

COURT. Q. If I understand you right, he had been entrusted with the warrant from time to time, which would authorize the clearing of nine chests, and to your knowledge he had only cleared eight? A. Yes, he took the warrant to the India-house, to clear those chests we had occasion for - there is no mark made on the warrant as to what was to be cleared, that is done on paper called a request paper; I gave no request paper for this chest, but Thompson could do that himself - I have never seen the warrant again; it becomes waste paper after the last chest is cleared.
JURY. Q. Did you ever ask for it? A. I asked Thompson for it, and made every search for it in every way; they are sometimes left at the India-house - I have not been able to get it.

ALGERNON PETTIT THOMPSON
(a prisoner). I was a clerk to Mr. Nicholson. I know the prisoner; I think the first dealing I had with him was on the 5th of August, when I sold him a chest of tea; I don't know the number of it, the number was described in the warrant; I don't know what has become of the warrant, it is always nailed on the last chest - I don't know whether this warrant was nailed on this chest - I met the prisoner that day in Crutched-friars
; I had not known him before; my cousin, Beresford Thompson, introduced him to me, and I sold him this chest of tea at 2s. 91/2d. lb. - I gave him the permit and the invoice in the name of Collins - my cousin told me to do so, and the prisoner referred me to Collins for the money - it was congou tea, and as well as I can remember it was 31 break.

COURT. Q. Did you ever see the chest in possession of the prisoner? A. No, I saw it placed on the knot of a porter, to carry it out - I stole the chest of tea - I don't know whether the duty was paid or not.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you known Collins? A. I had seen him, and spoken with him - I don't know that the prisoner was his servant - Collins keeps a marine store shop - I had sold a chest of tea to Collins before of my master's - he keeps a shop for the sale of grocery, and all sorts of necessaries for persons going abroad.

COURT. Q. You sold to the prisoner as an agent of Collins? A. Yes, and I received the money for this tea of Collins - my cousin took me to the prisoner, and I knew that I was going to deal with a person on behalf of Collins - it went to a person named Taylor in the Borough.

JURY. Q. Do you remember how many chests were on the warrant for that day? A. Only one was then remaining, I had cleared the other eight at different times before- I could get at the warrants before Mr. Nicholson came to town - Collins paid me on my taking a letter from the prisoner about two hours after I sold it.

JOHN SEALEY
. I am a labourer. On the 5th of August I was employed by the prisoner to carry a chest of tea to Mrs. Taylor in the Borough - I took it, and she refused to take it in; I brought it out of the house, to look for another person of the name of Taylor, and the prisoner came to me and said, "Take it on to my house;" he went with me, and showed me where his house was, in Great Suffolk-street; I took it there, and carried it up one pair of stairs - I don't recollect the marks on the chest, but it was a chest of congon.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Had you known the prisoner before? A. Yes, I knew him in a respectable line of business - I found there was some mistake when I got the chest to Mrs. Taylor's; he went into Mrs. Taylor's house, and had some conversation with her, and then he came out and said, "Take it on to my house" - it was between twelve and one o'clock in the day - I carried it on my knot - and the permit was in my pocket, which I gave to the prisoner when I got to his house - Collins' house is No. 8, East Smithfield - the prisoner's house was nearer to Mrs. Taylor's than Collins'.
COURT. Q. Did the prisoner go with you to get the tea? A. He stood outside the gateway while I went into the warehouse in Crutched-friars for it - he said he should go with me.

JURY. Q. Did any one go up the yard? A. No; I did not see any one that had any control over it; I took it by the permit which I got from the prisoner - I saw no warrant on it - I saw Thompson, but he did not say anything to me about it; I took it to Stone's from Mr. Taylor's, and the next day I took a chest away from Stones.
Cross-examined. Q. Who paid you for carrying the chest? A. Thompson paid me directly.
COURT. Q. What did he say when he paid you? A. He met me at the gate and said, "Here is the money for carrying this tea," and he gave me a shilling, which was the proper porterage to the Borough.

LUCY TAYLOR
. I am a grocer; I knew the prisoner about three years since; he was in business for himself, and had a shop at that time; Sealey brought this chest of tea to my shop - I said it was not for me; the prisoner came in just after and said, "Did you receive a chest of tea;" I said "No, a man brought it but it was not for me," and that he was gone down the Borough.
Prisoner's Defence. I acted as the agent of Mr. Collins - it was done for his benefit; he represented these to me as smuggled teas.

JOHN CARTER
. I served a subpoena at Mr. Collins house last Saturday, to attend here; he was not at home; I left it with Mrs. Collins, and told her to give it him directly he came home.

WILLIAM FIELD
. I am shopman to Mr. Collins; he is out of town - I cannot say where; I saw him on Saturday last - I have not seen him since; I did not see him start nor packing up his portmantuan - he never tells me where he goes; I don't know when he will return - I did not see the subpoena.

MR. AYCKBONE. Q. How many other persons has he in his employ? A. One porter; I know the prisoner, he is an agent - he has been at Mr. Collins,' he was there a little before the 12th of July; he was there constantly, keeping the books; I saw him there the beginning of August.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Then the prisoner acted as a kind of clerk to him? A. Yes - on the 8th of August, Mr. Collins said he was surprised Stone had not called, and after the shop was shut I went to Stone and got 41l. - I was told it was for three chests of tea.
NOT GUILTY .

There were
three other indictments against the prisoner for similar offences, upon which no evidence was offered .
NOT GUILTY .

The KING against
GEORGE RUSSELL
.

The Learned Judges, for whose decision the above case was reserved, have confirmed the
conviction . (See Fifth Sess. p. 471.)
